CWE-1007.Name: Insufficient Visual Distinction of Homoglyphs Presented to User
CWE-1007.Description: The product displays information or identifiers to a user, but the display mechanism does not make it easy for the user to distinguish between visually similar or identical glyphs (homoglyphs), which may cause the user to misinterpret a glyph and perform an unintended, insecure action.

CWE-1021.Name: Improper Restriction of Rendered UI Layers or Frames
CWE-1021.Description: The web application does not restrict or incorrectly restricts frame objects or UI layers that belong to another application or domain, which can lead to user confusion about which interface the user is interacting with.

CWE-1023.Name: Incomplete Comparison with Missing Factors
CWE-1023.Description: The product performs a comparison between entities that must consider multiple factors or characteristics of each entity, but the comparison does not include one or more of these factors.

CWE-1024.Name: Comparison of Incompatible Types
CWE-1024.Description: The product performs a comparison between two entities, but the entities are of different, incompatible types that cannot be guaranteed to provide correct results when they are directly compared.

CWE-1025.Name: Comparison Using Wrong Factors
CWE-1025.Description: The code performs a comparison between two entities, but the comparison examines the wrong factors or characteristics of the entities, which can lead to incorrect results and resultant weaknesses.

CWE-1038.Name: Insecure Automated Optimizations
CWE-1038.Description: The product uses a mechanism that automatically optimizes code, e.g. to improve a characteristic such as performance, but the optimizations can have an unintended side effect that might violate an intended security assumption.

CWE-1041.Name: Use of Redundant Code
CWE-1041.Description: The product has multiple functions, methods, procedures, macros, etc. that contain the same code.

CWE-1043.Name: Data Element Aggregating an Excessively Large Number of Non-Primitive Elements
CWE-1043.Description: The product uses a data element that has an excessively large number of sub-elements with non-primitive data types such as structures or aggregated objects.

CWE-1045.Name: Parent Class with a Virtual Destructor and a Child Class without a Virtual Destructor
CWE-1045.Description: A parent class has a virtual destructor method, but the parent has a child class that does not have a virtual destructor.

CWE-1046.Name: Creation of Immutable Text Using String Concatenation
CWE-1046.Description: The product creates an immutable text string using string concatenation operations.

CWE-1047.Name: Modules with Circular Dependencies
CWE-1047.Description: The product contains modules in which one module has references that cycle back to itself, i.e., there are circular dependencies.

CWE-1049.Name: Excessive Data Query Operations in a Large Data Table
CWE-1049.Description: The product performs a data query with a large number of joins and sub-queries on a large data table.

CWE-1050.Name: Excessive Platform Resource Consumption within a Loop
CWE-1050.Description: The product has a loop body or loop condition that contains a control element that directly or indirectly consumes platform resources, e.g. messaging, sessions, locks, or file descriptors.

CWE-1051.Name: Initialization with Hard-Coded Network Resource Configuration Data
CWE-1051.Description: The product initializes data using hard-coded values that act as network resource identifiers.

CWE-1052.Name: Excessive Use of Hard-Coded Literals in Initialization
CWE-1052.Description: The product initializes a data element using a hard-coded literal that is not a simple integer or static constant element.

CWE-1053.Name: Missing Documentation for Design
CWE-1053.Description: The product does not have documentation that represents how it is designed.

CWE-1054.Name: Invocation of a Control Element at an Unnecessarily Deep Horizontal Layer
CWE-1054.Description: The code at one architectural layer invokes code that resides at a deeper layer than the adjacent layer, i.e., the invocation skips at least one layer, and the invoked code is not part of a vertical utility layer that can be referenced from any horizontal layer.

CWE-1055.Name: Multiple Inheritance from Concrete Classes
CWE-1055.Description: The product contains a class with inheritance from more than one concrete class.

CWE-1056.Name: Invokable Control Element with Variadic Parameters
CWE-1056.Description: A named-callable or method control element has a signature that supports a variable (variadic) number of parameters or arguments.

CWE-1057.Name: Data Access Operations Outside of Expected Data Manager Component
CWE-1057.Description: The product uses a dedicated, central data manager component as required by design, but it contains code that performs data-access operations that do not use this data manager.

CWE-1059.Name: Insufficient Technical Documentation
CWE-1059.Description:
The product does not contain sufficient
         technical or engineering documentation (whether on paper or
         in electronic form) that contains descriptions of all the
         relevant software/hardware elements of the product, such as
         its usage, structure, architectural components, interfaces, design, implementation,
         configuration, operation, etc.

CWE-1060.Name: Excessive Number of Inefficient Server-Side Data Accesses
CWE-1060.Description: The product performs too many data queries without using efficient data processing functionality such as stored procedures.

CWE-1061.Name: Insufficient Encapsulation
CWE-1061.Description: The product does not sufficiently hide the internal representation and implementation details of data or methods, which might allow external components or modules to modify data unexpectedly, invoke unexpected functionality, or introduce dependencies that the programmer did not intend.

CWE-1062.Name: Parent Class with References to Child Class
CWE-1062.Description: The code has a parent class that contains references to a child class, its methods, or its members.

CWE-1063.Name: Creation of Class Instance within a Static Code Block
CWE-1063.Description: A static code block creates an instance of a class.

CWE-1064.Name: Invokable Control Element with Signature Containing an Excessive Number of Parameters
CWE-1064.Description: The product contains a function, subroutine, or method whose signature has an unnecessarily large number of parameters/arguments.

CWE-1066.Name: Missing Serialization Control Element
CWE-1066.Description: The product contains a serializable data element that does not have an associated serialization method.

CWE-1067.Name: Excessive Execution of Sequential Searches of Data Resource
CWE-1067.Description: The product contains a data query against an SQL table or view that is configured in a way that does not utilize an index and may cause sequential searches to be performed.

CWE-1068.Name: Inconsistency Between Implementation and Documented Design
CWE-1068.Description: The implementation of the product is not consistent with the design as described within the relevant documentation.

CWE-1069.Name: Empty Exception Block
CWE-1069.Description: An invokable code block contains an exception handling block that does not contain any code, i.e. is empty.

CWE-1070.Name: Serializable Data Element Containing non-Serializable Item Elements
CWE-1070.Description: The product contains a serializable, storable data element such as a field or member, but the data element contains member elements that are not serializable.

CWE-1071.Name: Empty Code Block
CWE-1071.Description: The source code contains a block that does not contain any code, i.e., the block is empty.

CWE-1072.Name: Data Resource Access without Use of Connection Pooling
CWE-1072.Description: The product accesses a data resource through a database without using a connection pooling capability.

CWE-1074.Name: Class with Excessively Deep Inheritance
CWE-1074.Description: A class has an inheritance level that is too high, i.e., it has a large number of parent classes.

CWE-1075.Name: Unconditional Control Flow Transfer outside of Switch Block
CWE-1075.Description: The product performs unconditional control transfer (such as a "goto") in code outside of a branching structure such as a switch block.

CWE-1076.Name: Insufficient Adherence to Expected Conventions
CWE-1076.Description: The product's architecture, source code, design, documentation, or other artifact does not follow required conventions.

CWE-1077.Name: Floating Point Comparison with Incorrect Operator
CWE-1077.Description:
The code performs a comparison such as an
        equality test between two float (floating point) values, but
        it uses comparison operators that do not account for the
        possibility of loss of precision.

CWE-1078.Name: Inappropriate Source Code Style or Formatting
CWE-1078.Description:
The source code does not follow
				desired style or formatting for indentation, white
				space, comments, etc.

CWE-1079.Name: Parent Class without Virtual Destructor Method
CWE-1079.Description: A parent class contains one or more child classes, but the parent class does not have a virtual destructor method.

CWE-1080.Name: Source Code File with Excessive Number of Lines of Code
CWE-1080.Description: A source code file has too many lines of code.

CWE-1082.Name: Class Instance Self Destruction Control Element
CWE-1082.Description: The code contains a class instance that calls the method or function to delete or destroy itself.

CWE-1083.Name: Data Access from Outside Expected Data Manager Component
CWE-1083.Description: The product is intended to manage data access through a particular data manager component such as a relational or non-SQL database, but it contains code that performs data access operations without using that component.

CWE-1084.Name: Invokable Control Element with Excessive File or Data Access Operations
CWE-1084.Description: A function or method contains too many operations that utilize a data manager or file resource.

CWE-1085.Name: Invokable Control Element with Excessive Volume of Commented-out Code
CWE-1085.Description: A function, method, procedure, etc. contains an excessive amount of code that has been commented out within its body.

CWE-1086.Name: Class with Excessive Number of Child Classes
CWE-1086.Description: A class contains an unnecessarily large number of children.

CWE-1087.Name: Class with Virtual Method without a Virtual Destructor
CWE-1087.Description: A class contains a virtual method, but the method does not have an associated virtual destructor.

CWE-1088.Name: Synchronous Access of Remote Resource without Timeout
CWE-1088.Description: The code has a synchronous call to a remote resource, but there is no timeout for the call, or the timeout is set to infinite.

CWE-1090.Name: Method Containing Access of a Member Element from Another Class
CWE-1090.Description: A method for a class performs an operation that directly accesses a member element from another class.

CWE-1091.Name: Use of Object without Invoking Destructor Method
CWE-1091.Description: The product contains a method that accesses an object but does not later invoke the element's associated finalize/destructor method.

CWE-1092.Name: Use of Same Invokable Control Element in Multiple Architectural Layers
CWE-1092.Description: The product uses the same control element across multiple architectural layers.

CWE-1093.Name: Excessively Complex Data Representation
CWE-1093.Description: The product uses an unnecessarily complex internal representation for its data structures or interrelationships between those structures.

CWE-1094.Name: Excessive Index Range Scan for a Data Resource
CWE-1094.Description: The product contains an index range scan for a large data table, but the scan can cover a large number of rows.

CWE-1095.Name: Loop Condition Value Update within the Loop
CWE-1095.Description: The product uses a loop with a control flow condition based on a value that is updated within the body of the loop.

CWE-1096.Name: Singleton Class Instance Creation without Proper Locking or Synchronization
CWE-1096.Description: The product implements a Singleton design pattern but does not use appropriate locking or other synchronization mechanism to ensure that the singleton class is only instantiated once.

CWE-1097.Name: Persistent Storable Data Element without Associated Comparison Control Element
CWE-1097.Description: The product uses a storable data element that does not have all of the associated functions or methods that are necessary to support comparison.

CWE-1098.Name: Data Element containing Pointer Item without Proper Copy Control Element
CWE-1098.Description: The code contains a data element with a pointer that does not have an associated copy or constructor method.

CWE-1099.Name: Inconsistent Naming Conventions for Identifiers
CWE-1099.Description: The product's code, documentation, or other artifacts do not consistently use the same naming conventions for variables, callables, groups of related callables, I/O capabilities, data types, file names, or similar types of elements.

CWE-1100.Name: Insufficient Isolation of System-Dependent Functions
CWE-1100.Description: The product or code does not isolate system-dependent functionality into separate standalone modules.

CWE-1102.Name: Reliance on Machine-Dependent Data Representation
CWE-1102.Description: The code uses a data representation that relies on low-level data representation or constructs that may vary across different processors, physical machines, OSes, or other physical components.

CWE-1103.Name: Use of Platform-Dependent Third Party Components
CWE-1103.Description: The product relies on third-party components that do not provide equivalent functionality across all desirable platforms.

CWE-1104.Name: Use of Unmaintained Third Party Components
CWE-1104.Description: The product relies on third-party components that are not actively supported or maintained by the original developer or a trusted proxy for the original developer.

CWE-1106.Name: Insufficient Use of Symbolic Constants
CWE-1106.Description: The source code uses literal constants that may need to change or evolve over time, instead of using symbolic constants.

CWE-1107.Name: Insufficient Isolation of Symbolic Constant Definitions
CWE-1107.Description: The source code uses symbolic constants, but it does not sufficiently place the definitions of these constants into a more centralized or isolated location.

CWE-1108.Name: Excessive Reliance on Global Variables
CWE-1108.Description: The code is structured in a way that relies too much on using or setting global variables throughout various points in the code, instead of preserving the associated information in a narrower, more local context.

CWE-1109.Name: Use of Same Variable for Multiple Purposes
CWE-1109.Description: The code contains a callable, block, or other code element in which the same variable is used to control more than one unique task or store more than one instance of data.

CWE-111.Name: Direct Use of Unsafe JNI
CWE-111.Description: When a Java application uses the Java Native Interface (JNI) to call code written in another programming language, it can expose the application to weaknesses in that code, even if those weaknesses cannot occur in Java.

CWE-1110.Name: Incomplete Design Documentation
CWE-1110.Description: The product's design documentation does not adequately describe control flow, data flow, system initialization, relationships between tasks, components, rationales, or other important aspects of the design.

CWE-1111.Name: Incomplete I/O Documentation
CWE-1111.Description: The product's documentation does not adequately define inputs, outputs, or system/software interfaces.

CWE-1112.Name: Incomplete Documentation of Program Execution
CWE-1112.Description: The document does not fully define all mechanisms that are used to control or influence how product-specific programs are executed.

CWE-1113.Name: Inappropriate Comment Style
CWE-1113.Description: The source code uses comment styles or formats that are inconsistent or do not follow expected standards for the product.

CWE-1114.Name: Inappropriate Whitespace Style
CWE-1114.Description: The source code contains whitespace that is inconsistent across the code or does not follow expected standards for the product.

CWE-1115.Name: Source Code Element without Standard Prologue
CWE-1115.Description: The source code contains elements such as source files  that do not consistently provide a prologue or header that has been standardized for the project.

CWE-1116.Name: Inaccurate Comments
CWE-1116.Description: The source code contains comments that do not accurately describe or explain aspects of the portion of the code with which the comment is associated.

CWE-1117.Name: Callable with Insufficient Behavioral Summary
CWE-1117.Description: The code contains a function or method whose signature and/or associated inline documentation does not sufficiently describe the callable's inputs, outputs, side effects, assumptions, or return codes.

CWE-1118.Name: Insufficient Documentation of Error Handling Techniques
CWE-1118.Description: The documentation does not sufficiently describe the techniques that are used for error handling, exception processing, or similar mechanisms.

CWE-1119.Name: Excessive Use of Unconditional Branching
CWE-1119.Description: The code uses too many unconditional branches (such as "goto").

CWE-112.Name: Missing XML Validation
CWE-112.Description: The product accepts XML from an untrusted source but does not validate the XML against the proper schema.

CWE-1120.Name: Excessive Code Complexity
CWE-1120.Description: The code is too complex, as calculated using a well-defined, quantitative measure.

CWE-1121.Name: Excessive McCabe Cyclomatic Complexity
CWE-1121.Description:
The code contains McCabe cyclomatic complexity that exceeds a
	desirable maximum.

CWE-1122.Name: Excessive Halstead Complexity
CWE-1122.Description: The code is structured in a way that a Halstead complexity measure exceeds a desirable maximum.

CWE-1123.Name: Excessive Use of Self-Modifying Code
CWE-1123.Description: The product uses too much self-modifying code.

CWE-1124.Name: Excessively Deep Nesting
CWE-1124.Description: The code contains a callable or other code grouping in which the nesting / branching is too deep.

CWE-1125.Name: Excessive Attack Surface
CWE-1125.Description: The product has an attack surface whose quantitative measurement exceeds a desirable maximum.

CWE-1126.Name: Declaration of Variable with Unnecessarily Wide Scope
CWE-1126.Description: The source code declares a variable in one scope, but the variable is only used within a narrower scope.

CWE-1127.Name: Compilation with Insufficient Warnings or Errors
CWE-1127.Description: The code is compiled without sufficient warnings enabled, which may prevent the detection of subtle bugs or quality issues.

CWE-114.Name: Process Control
CWE-114.Description: Executing commands or loading libraries from an untrusted source or in an untrusted environment can cause an application to execute malicious commands (and payloads) on behalf of an attacker.

CWE-115.Name: Misinterpretation of Input
CWE-115.Description: The product misinterprets an input, whether from an attacker or another product, in a security-relevant fashion.

CWE-116.Name: Improper Encoding or Escaping of Output
CWE-116.Description: The product prepares a structured message for communication with another component, but encoding or escaping of the data is either missing or done incorrectly. As a result, the intended structure of the message is not preserved.

CWE-1164.Name: Irrelevant Code
CWE-1164.Description:
The product contains code that is not essential for execution,
	     i.e. makes no state changes and has no side effects that alter
	     data or control flow, such that removal of the code would have no impact
	     to functionality or correctness.

CWE-117.Name: Improper Output Neutralization for Logs
CWE-117.Description: The product does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes output that is written to logs.

CWE-1173.Name: Improper Use of Validation Framework
CWE-1173.Description: The product does not use, or incorrectly uses, an input validation framework that is provided by the source language or an independent library.

CWE-1176.Name: Inefficient CPU Computation
CWE-1176.Description:
The product performs CPU computations using
         algorithms that are not as efficient as they could be for the
         needs of the developer, i.e., the computations can be
         optimized further.

CWE-1177.Name: Use of Prohibited Code
CWE-1177.Description:
The product uses a function, library, or third party component
	     that has been explicitly prohibited, whether by the developer or
	     the customer.

CWE-1188.Name: Initialization of a Resource with an Insecure Default
CWE-1188.Description: The product initializes or sets a resource with a default that is intended to be changed by the administrator, but the default is not secure.

CWE-1189.Name: Improper Isolation of Shared Resources on System-on-a-Chip (SoC)
CWE-1189.Description: The System-On-a-Chip (SoC) does not properly isolate shared resources between trusted and untrusted agents.

CWE-119.Name: Improper Restriction of Operations within the Bounds of a Memory Buffer
CWE-119.Description: The product performs operations on a memory buffer, but it reads from or writes to a memory location outside the buffer's intended boundary. This may result in read or write operations on unexpected memory locations that could be linked to other variables, data structures, or internal program data.

CWE-1190.Name: DMA Device Enabled Too Early in Boot Phase
CWE-1190.Description: The product enables a Direct Memory Access (DMA) capable device before the security configuration settings are established, which allows an attacker to extract data from or gain privileges on the product.

CWE-1192.Name: Improper Identifier for IP Block used in System-On-Chip (SOC)
CWE-1192.Description: The System-on-Chip (SoC) does not have unique, immutable identifiers for each of its components.

CWE-1193.Name: Power-On of Untrusted Execution Core Before Enabling Fabric Access Control
CWE-1193.Description: The product enables components that contain untrusted firmware before memory and fabric access controls have been enabled.

CWE-120.Name: Buffer Copy without Checking Size of Input ('Classic Buffer Overflow')
CWE-120.Description: The product copies an input buffer to an output buffer without verifying that the size of the input buffer is less than the size of the output buffer, leading to a buffer overflow.

CWE-1204.Name: Generation of Weak Initialization Vector (IV)
CWE-1204.Description:
The product uses a cryptographic primitive that uses an Initialization
			Vector (IV), but the product does not generate IVs that are
			sufficiently unpredictable or unique according to the expected
			cryptographic requirements for that primitive.

CWE-121.Name: Stack-based Buffer Overflow
CWE-121.Description: A stack-based buffer overflow condition is a condition where the buffer being overwritten is allocated on the stack (i.e., is a local variable or, rarely, a parameter to a function).

CWE-122.Name: Heap-based Buffer Overflow
CWE-122.Description: A heap overflow condition is a buffer overflow, where the buffer that can be overwritten is allocated in the heap portion of memory, generally meaning that the buffer was allocated using a routine such as malloc().

CWE-1221.Name: Incorrect Register Defaults or Module Parameters
CWE-1221.Description: Hardware description language code incorrectly defines register defaults or hardware Intellectual Property (IP) parameters to insecure values.

CWE-1222.Name: Insufficient Granularity of Address Regions Protected by Register Locks
CWE-1222.Description: The product defines a large address region protected from modification by the same register lock control bit. This results in a conflict between the functional requirement that some addresses need to be writable by software during operation and the security requirement that the system configuration lock bit must be set during the boot process.

CWE-1229.Name: Creation of Emergent Resource
CWE-1229.Description: The product manages resources or behaves in a way that indirectly creates a new, distinct resource that can be used by attackers in violation of the intended policy.

CWE-123.Name: Write-what-where Condition
CWE-123.Description: Any condition where the attacker has the ability to write an arbitrary value to an arbitrary location, often as the result of a buffer overflow.

CWE-1230.Name: Exposure of Sensitive Information Through Metadata
CWE-1230.Description: The product prevents direct access to a resource containing sensitive information, but it does not sufficiently limit access to metadata that is derived from the original, sensitive information.

CWE-1235.Name: Incorrect Use of Autoboxing and Unboxing for Performance Critical Operations
CWE-1235.Description: The code uses boxed primitives, which may introduce inefficiencies into performance-critical operations.

CWE-1239.Name: Improper Zeroization of Hardware Register
CWE-1239.Description: The hardware product does not properly clear sensitive information from built-in registers when the user of the hardware block changes.

CWE-124.Name: Buffer Underwrite ('Buffer Underflow')
CWE-124.Description: The product writes to a buffer using an index or pointer that references a memory location prior to the beginning of the buffer.

CWE-1240.Name: Use of a Cryptographic Primitive with a Risky Implementation
CWE-1240.Description: To fulfill the need for a cryptographic primitive, the product implements a cryptographic algorithm using a non-standard, unproven, or disallowed/non-compliant cryptographic implementation.

CWE-1241.Name: Use of Predictable Algorithm in Random Number Generator
CWE-1241.Description: The device uses an algorithm that is predictable and generates a pseudo-random number.

CWE-1243.Name: Sensitive Non-Volatile Information Not Protected During Debug
CWE-1243.Description: Access to security-sensitive information stored in fuses is not limited during debug.

CWE-1244.Name: Internal Asset Exposed to Unsafe Debug Access Level or State
CWE-1244.Description:
The product uses physical debug or test
        interfaces with support for multiple access levels, but it
        assigns the wrong debug access level to an internal asset,
        providing unintended access to the asset from untrusted debug
        agents.

CWE-1246.Name: Improper Write Handling in Limited-write Non-Volatile Memories
CWE-1246.Description: The product does not implement or incorrectly implements wear leveling operations in limited-write non-volatile memories.

CWE-1247.Name: Improper Protection Against Voltage and Clock Glitches
CWE-1247.Description: The device does not contain or contains incorrectly implemented circuitry or sensors to detect and mitigate voltage and clock glitches and protect sensitive information or software contained on the device.

CWE-1249.Name: Application-Level Admin Tool with Inconsistent View of Underlying Operating System
CWE-1249.Description: The product provides an application for administrators to manage parts of the underlying operating system, but the application does not accurately identify all of the relevant entities or resources that exist in the OS; that is, the application's model of the OS's state is inconsistent with the OS's actual state.

CWE-125.Name: Out-of-bounds Read
CWE-125.Description: The product reads data past the end, or before the beginning, of the intended buffer.

CWE-1251.Name: Mirrored Regions with Different Values
CWE-1251.Description: The product's architecture mirrors regions without ensuring that their contents always stay in sync.

CWE-1254.Name: Incorrect Comparison Logic Granularity
CWE-1254.Description: The product's comparison logic is performed over a series of steps rather than across the entire string in one operation. If there is a comparison logic failure on one of these steps, the operation may be vulnerable to a timing attack that can result in the interception of the process for nefarious purposes.

CWE-1255.Name: Comparison Logic is Vulnerable to Power Side-Channel Attacks
CWE-1255.Description: A device's real time power consumption may be monitored during security token evaluation and the information gleaned may be used to determine the value of the reference token.

CWE-1258.Name: Exposure of Sensitive System Information Due to Uncleared Debug Information
CWE-1258.Description: The hardware does not fully clear security-sensitive values, such as keys and intermediate values in cryptographic operations, when debug mode is entered.

CWE-126.Name: Buffer Over-read
CWE-126.Description: The product reads from a buffer using buffer access mechanisms such as indexes or pointers that reference memory locations after the targeted buffer.

CWE-1261.Name: Improper Handling of Single Event Upsets
CWE-1261.Description: The hardware logic does not effectively handle when single-event upsets (SEUs) occur.

CWE-1264.Name: Hardware Logic with Insecure De-Synchronization between Control and Data Channels
CWE-1264.Description: The hardware logic for error handling and security checks can incorrectly forward data before the security check is complete.

CWE-1265.Name: Unintended Reentrant Invocation of Non-reentrant Code Via Nested Calls
CWE-1265.Description: During execution of non-reentrant code, the product performs a call that unintentionally produces a nested invocation of the non-reentrant code.

CWE-1266.Name: Improper Scrubbing of Sensitive Data from Decommissioned Device
CWE-1266.Description: The product does not properly provide a capability for the product administrator to remove sensitive data at the time the product is decommissioned.  A scrubbing capability could be missing, insufficient, or incorrect.

CWE-1267.Name: Policy Uses Obsolete Encoding
CWE-1267.Description: The product uses an obsolete encoding mechanism to implement access controls.

CWE-127.Name: Buffer Under-read
CWE-127.Description: The product reads from a buffer using buffer access mechanisms such as indexes or pointers that reference memory locations prior to the targeted buffer.

CWE-1270.Name: Generation of Incorrect Security Tokens
CWE-1270.Description: The product implements a Security Token mechanism to differentiate what actions are allowed or disallowed when a transaction originates from an entity. However, the Security Tokens generated in the system are incorrect.

CWE-1271.Name: Uninitialized Value on Reset for Registers Holding Security Settings
CWE-1271.Description: Security-critical logic is not set to a known value on reset.

CWE-1272.Name: Sensitive Information Uncleared Before Debug/Power State Transition
CWE-1272.Description: The product performs a power or debug state transition, but it does not clear sensitive information that should no longer be accessible due to changes to information access restrictions.

CWE-1273.Name: Device Unlock Credential Sharing
CWE-1273.Description: The credentials necessary for unlocking a device are shared across multiple parties and may expose sensitive information.

CWE-128.Name: Wrap-around Error
CWE-128.Description: Wrap around errors occur whenever a value is incremented past the maximum value for its type and therefore "wraps around" to a very small, negative, or undefined value.

CWE-1280.Name: Access Control Check Implemented After Asset is Accessed
CWE-1280.Description: A product's hardware-based access control check occurs after the asset has been accessed.

CWE-1282.Name: Assumed-Immutable Data is Stored in Writable Memory
CWE-1282.Description: Immutable data, such as a first-stage bootloader, device identifiers, and "write-once" configuration settings are stored in writable memory that can be re-programmed or updated in the field.

CWE-1283.Name: Mutable Attestation or Measurement Reporting Data
CWE-1283.Description: The register contents used for attestation or measurement reporting data to verify boot flow are modifiable by an adversary.

CWE-1284.Name: Improper Validation of Specified Quantity in Input
CWE-1284.Description: The product receives input that is expected to specify a quantity (such as size or length), but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the quantity has the required properties.

CWE-1285.Name: Improper Validation of Specified Index, Position, or Offset in Input
CWE-1285.Description: The product receives input that is expected to specify an index, position, or offset into an indexable resource such as a buffer or file, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the specified index/position/offset has the required properties.

CWE-1286.Name: Improper Validation of Syntactic Correctness of Input
CWE-1286.Description: The product receives input that is expected to be well-formed - i.e., to comply with a certain syntax - but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input complies with the syntax.

CWE-1287.Name: Improper Validation of Specified Type of Input
CWE-1287.Description: The product receives input that is expected to be of a certain type, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input is actually of the expected type.

CWE-1288.Name: Improper Validation of Consistency within Input
CWE-1288.Description: The product receives a complex input with multiple elements or fields that must be consistent with each other, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input is actually consistent.

CWE-1289.Name: Improper Validation of Unsafe Equivalence in Input
CWE-1289.Description: The product receives an input value that is used as a resource identifier or other type of reference, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input is equivalent to a potentially-unsafe value.

CWE-129.Name: Improper Validation of Array Index
CWE-129.Description: The product uses untrusted input when calculating or using an array index, but the product does not validate or incorrectly validates the index to ensure the index references a valid position within the array.

CWE-1293.Name: Missing Source Correlation of Multiple Independent Data
CWE-1293.Description: The product relies on one source of data, preventing the ability to detect if an adversary has compromised a data source.

CWE-1295.Name: Debug Messages Revealing Unnecessary Information
CWE-1295.Description: The product fails to adequately prevent the revealing of unnecessary and potentially sensitive system information within debugging messages.

CWE-1299.Name: Missing Protection Mechanism for Alternate Hardware Interface
CWE-1299.Description:
The lack of protections on alternate paths to access
                control-protected assets (such as unprotected shadow registers
                and other external facing unguarded interfaces) allows an
                attacker to bypass existing protections to the asset that are
		only performed against the primary path.

CWE-130.Name: Improper Handling of Length Parameter Inconsistency
CWE-130.Description: The product parses a formatted message or structure, but it does not handle or incorrectly handles a length field that is inconsistent with the actual length of the associated data.

CWE-1300.Name: Improper Protection of Physical Side Channels
CWE-1300.Description:
The device does not contain sufficient protection
	mechanisms to prevent physical side channels from exposing
	sensitive information due to patterns in physically observable
	phenomena such as variations in power consumption,
	electromagnetic emissions (EME), or acoustic emissions.

CWE-1301.Name: Insufficient or Incomplete Data Removal within Hardware Component
CWE-1301.Description: The product's data removal process does not completely delete all data and potentially sensitive information within hardware components.

CWE-1302.Name: Missing Source Identifier in Entity Transactions on a System-On-Chip (SOC)
CWE-1302.Description: The product implements a security identifier mechanism to differentiate what actions are allowed or disallowed when a transaction originates from an entity. A transaction is sent without a security identifier.

CWE-1303.Name: Non-Transparent Sharing of Microarchitectural Resources
CWE-1303.Description: Hardware structures shared across execution contexts (e.g., caches and branch predictors) can violate the expected architecture isolation between contexts.

CWE-1314.Name: Missing Write Protection for Parametric Data Values
CWE-1314.Description: The device does not write-protect the parametric data values for sensors that scale the sensor value, allowing untrusted software to manipulate the apparent result and potentially damage hardware or cause operational failure.

CWE-1321.Name: Improperly Controlled Modification of Object Prototype Attributes ('Prototype Pollution')
CWE-1321.Description: The product receives input from an upstream component that specifies attributes that are to be initialized or updated in an object, but it does not properly control modifications of attributes of the object prototype.

CWE-1325.Name: Improperly Controlled Sequential Memory Allocation
CWE-1325.Description: The product manages a group of objects or resources and performs a separate memory allocation for each object, but it does not properly limit the total amount of memory that is consumed by all of the combined objects.

CWE-1327.Name: Binding to an Unrestricted IP Address
CWE-1327.Description: The product assigns the address 0.0.0.0 for a database server, a cloud service/instance, or any computing resource that communicates remotely.

CWE-1328.Name: Security Version Number Mutable to Older Versions
CWE-1328.Description: Security-version number in hardware is mutable, resulting in the ability to downgrade (roll-back) the boot firmware to vulnerable code versions.

CWE-1329.Name: Reliance on Component That is Not Updateable
CWE-1329.Description: The product contains a component that cannot be updated or patched in order to remove vulnerabilities or significant bugs.

CWE-1330.Name: Remanent Data Readable after Memory Erase
CWE-1330.Description: Confidential information stored in memory circuits is readable or recoverable after being cleared or erased.

CWE-1331.Name: Improper Isolation of Shared Resources in Network On Chip (NoC)
CWE-1331.Description: The Network On Chip (NoC) does not isolate or incorrectly isolates its on-chip-fabric and internal resources such that they are shared between trusted and untrusted agents, creating timing channels.

CWE-1332.Name: Improper Handling of Faults that Lead to Instruction Skips
CWE-1332.Description: The device is missing or incorrectly implements circuitry or sensors that detect and mitigate the skipping of security-critical CPU instructions when they occur.

CWE-1333.Name: Inefficient Regular Expression Complexity
CWE-1333.Description: The product uses a regular expression with an inefficient, possibly exponential worst-case computational complexity that consumes excessive CPU cycles.

CWE-1335.Name: Incorrect Bitwise Shift of Integer
CWE-1335.Description: An integer value is specified to be shifted by a negative amount or an amount greater than or equal to the number of bits contained in the value causing an unexpected or indeterminate result.

CWE-1336.Name: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements Used in a Template Engine
CWE-1336.Description: The product uses a template engine to insert or process externally-influenced input, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements or syntax that can be interpreted as template expressions or other code directives when processed by the engine.

CWE-1339.Name: Insufficient Precision or Accuracy of a Real Number
CWE-1339.Description: The product processes a real number with an implementation in which the number's representation does not preserve required accuracy and precision in its fractional part, causing an incorrect result.

CWE-134.Name: Use of Externally-Controlled Format String
CWE-134.Description: The product uses a function that accepts a format string as an argument, but the format string originates from an external source.

CWE-1342.Name: Information Exposure through Microarchitectural State after Transient Execution
CWE-1342.Description: The processor does not properly clear microarchitectural state after incorrect microcode assists or speculative execution, resulting in transient execution.

CWE-135.Name: Incorrect Calculation of Multi-Byte String Length
CWE-135.Description: The product does not correctly calculate the length of strings that can contain wide or multi-byte characters.

CWE-1351.Name: Improper Handling of Hardware Behavior in Exceptionally Cold Environments
CWE-1351.Description:
A hardware device, or the firmware running on it, is
                missing or has incorrect protection features to maintain
                goals of security primitives when the device is cooled below
                standard operating temperatures.

CWE-1357.Name: Reliance on Insufficiently Trustworthy Component
CWE-1357.Description: The product is built from multiple separate components, but it uses a component that is not sufficiently trusted to meet expectations for security, reliability, updateability, and maintainability.

CWE-138.Name: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements
CWE-138.Description: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as control elements or syntactic markers when they are sent to a downstream component.

CWE-1385.Name: Missing Origin Validation in WebSockets
CWE-1385.Description: The product uses a WebSocket, but it does not properly verify that the source of data or communication is valid.

CWE-1386.Name: Insecure Operation on Windows Junction / Mount Point
CWE-1386.Description: The product opens a file or directory, but it does not properly prevent the name from being associated with a junction or mount point to a destination that is outside of the intended control sphere.

CWE-1389.Name: Incorrect Parsing of Numbers with Different Radices
CWE-1389.Description: The product parses numeric input assuming base 10 (decimal) values, but it does not account for inputs that use a different base number (radix).

CWE-1390.Name: Weak Authentication
CWE-1390.Description: The product uses an authentication mechanism to restrict access to specific users or identities, but the mechanism does not sufficiently prove that the claimed identity is correct.

CWE-1391.Name: Use of Weak Credentials
CWE-1391.Description: The product uses weak credentials (such as a default key or hard-coded password) that can be calculated, derived, reused, or guessed by an attacker.

CWE-1392.Name: Use of Default Credentials
CWE-1392.Description: The product uses default credentials (such as passwords or cryptographic keys) for potentially critical functionality.

CWE-1393.Name: Use of Default Password
CWE-1393.Description: The product uses default passwords for potentially critical functionality.

CWE-1394.Name: Use of Default Cryptographic Key
CWE-1394.Description: The product uses a default cryptographic key for potentially critical functionality.

CWE-1395.Name: Dependency on Vulnerable Third-Party Component
CWE-1395.Description: The product has a dependency on a third-party component that contains one or more known vulnerabilities.

CWE-14.Name: Compiler Removal of Code to Clear Buffers
CWE-14.Description: Sensitive memory is cleared according to the source code, but compiler optimizations leave the memory untouched when it is not read from again, aka "dead store removal."

CWE-140.Name: Improper Neutralization of Delimiters
CWE-140.Description: The product does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes delimiters.

CWE-141.Name: Improper Neutralization of Parameter/Argument Delimiters
CWE-141.Description: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as parameter or argument delimiters when they are sent to a downstream component.

CWE-1419.Name: Incorrect Initialization of Resource
CWE-1419.Description: The product attempts to initialize a resource but does not correctly do so, which might leave the resource in an unexpected, incorrect, or insecure state when it is accessed.

CWE-142.Name: Improper Neutralization of Value Delimiters
CWE-142.Description: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as value delimiters when they are sent to a downstream component.

CWE-1420.Name: Exposure of Sensitive Information during Transient Execution
CWE-1420.Description: A processor event or prediction may allow incorrect operations (or correct operations with incorrect data) to execute transiently, potentially exposing data over a covert channel.

CWE-1421.Name: Exposure of Sensitive Information in Shared Microarchitectural Structures during Transient Execution
CWE-1421.Description:
A processor event may allow transient operations to access
			architecturally restricted data (for example, in another address
			space) in a shared microarchitectural structure (for example, a CPU
			cache), potentially exposing the data over a covert channel.

CWE-1422.Name: Exposure of Sensitive Information caused by Incorrect Data Forwarding during Transient Execution
CWE-1422.Description:
A processor event or prediction may allow incorrect or stale data to
		  be forwarded to transient operations, potentially exposing data over a
		  covert channel.

CWE-1423.Name: Exposure of Sensitive Information caused by Shared Microarchitectural Predictor State that Influences Transient Execution
CWE-1423.Description:
Shared microarchitectural predictor state may allow code to influence
				transient execution across a hardware boundary, potentially exposing
				data that is accessible beyond the boundary over a covert channel.

CWE-1426.Name: Improper Validation of Generative AI Output
CWE-1426.Description:
The product invokes a generative AI/ML
			component whose behaviors and outputs cannot be directly
			controlled, but the product does not validate or
			insufficiently validates the outputs to ensure that they
			align with the intended security, content, or privacy
			policy.

CWE-143.Name: Improper Neutralization of Record Delimiters
CWE-143.Description: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as record delimiters when they are sent to a downstream component.

CWE-144.Name: Improper Neutralization of Line Delimiters
CWE-144.Description: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as line delimiters when they are sent to a downstream component.

CWE-145.Name: Improper Neutralization of Section Delimiters
CWE-145.Description: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as section delimiters when they are sent to a downstream component.

CWE-146.Name: Improper Neutralization of Expression/Command Delimiters
CWE-146.Description: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as expression or command delimiters when they are sent to a downstream component.

CWE-147.Name: Improper Neutralization of Input Terminators
CWE-147.Description: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as input terminators when they are sent to a downstream component.

CWE-148.Name: Improper Neutralization of Input Leaders
CWE-148.Description: The product does not properly handle when a leading character or sequence ("leader") is missing or malformed, or if multiple leaders are used when only one should be allowed.

CWE-149.Name: Improper Neutralization of Quoting Syntax
CWE-149.Description: Quotes injected into a product can be used to compromise a system. As data are parsed, an injected/absent/duplicate/malformed use of quotes may cause the process to take unexpected actions.

CWE-15.Name: External Control of System or Configuration Setting
CWE-15.Description: One or more system settings or configuration elements can be externally controlled by a user.

CWE-150.Name: Improper Neutralization of Escape, Meta, or Control Sequences
CWE-150.Description: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as escape, meta, or control character sequences when they are sent to a downstream component.

CWE-151.Name: Improper Neutralization of Comment Delimiters
CWE-151.Description: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as comment delimiters when they are sent to a downstream component.

CWE-152.Name: Improper Neutralization of Macro Symbols
CWE-152.Description: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as macro symbols when they are sent to a downstream component.

CWE-153.Name: Improper Neutralization of Substitution Characters
CWE-153.Description: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as substitution characters when they are sent to a downstream component.

CWE-154.Name: Improper Neutralization of Variable Name Delimiters
CWE-154.Description: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as variable name delimiters when they are sent to a downstream component.

CWE-155.Name: Improper Neutralization of Wildcards or Matching Symbols
CWE-155.Description: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as wildcards or matching symbols when they are sent to a downstream component.

CWE-156.Name: Improper Neutralization of Whitespace
CWE-156.Description: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could be interpreted as whitespace when they are sent to a downstream component.

CWE-157.Name: Failure to Sanitize Paired Delimiters
CWE-157.Description: The product does not properly handle the characters that are used to mark the beginning and ending of a group of entities, such as parentheses, brackets, and braces.

CWE-158.Name: Improper Neutralization of Null Byte or NUL Character
CWE-158.Description: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes NUL characters or null bytes when they are sent to a downstream component.

CWE-159.Name: Improper Handling of Invalid Use of Special Elements
CWE-159.Description: The product does not properly filter, remove, quote, or otherwise manage the invalid use of special elements in user-controlled input, which could cause adverse effect on its behavior and integrity.

CWE-160.Name: Improper Neutralization of Leading Special Elements
CWE-160.Description: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes leading special elements that could be interpreted in unexpected ways when they are sent to a downstream component.

CWE-161.Name: Improper Neutralization of Multiple Leading Special Elements
CWE-161.Description: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes multiple leading special elements that could be interpreted in unexpected ways when they are sent to a downstream component.

CWE-162.Name: Improper Neutralization of Trailing Special Elements
CWE-162.Description: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes trailing special elements that could be interpreted in unexpected ways when they are sent to a downstream component.

CWE-163.Name: Improper Neutralization of Multiple Trailing Special Elements
CWE-163.Description: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes multiple trailing special elements that could be interpreted in unexpected ways when they are sent to a downstream component.

CWE-164.Name: Improper Neutralization of Internal Special Elements
CWE-164.Description: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes internal special elements that could be interpreted in unexpected ways when they are sent to a downstream component.

CWE-165.Name: Improper Neutralization of Multiple Internal Special Elements
CWE-165.Description: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes multiple internal special elements that could be interpreted in unexpected ways when they are sent to a downstream component.

CWE-166.Name: Improper Handling of Missing Special Element
CWE-166.Description: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not handle or incorrectly handles when an expected special element is missing.

CWE-167.Name: Improper Handling of Additional Special Element
CWE-167.Description: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not handle or incorrectly handles when an additional unexpected special element is provided.

CWE-168.Name: Improper Handling of Inconsistent Special Elements
CWE-168.Description: The product does not properly handle input in which an inconsistency exists between two or more special characters or reserved words.

CWE-170.Name: Improper Null Termination
CWE-170.Description: The product does not terminate or incorrectly terminates a string or array with a null character or equivalent terminator.

CWE-172.Name: Encoding Error
CWE-172.Description: The product does not properly encode or decode the data, resulting in unexpected values.

CWE-173.Name: Improper Handling of Alternate Encoding
CWE-173.Description: The product does not properly handle when an input uses an alternate encoding that is valid for the control sphere to which the input is being sent.

CWE-174.Name: Double Decoding of the Same Data
CWE-174.Description: The product decodes the same input twice, which can limit the effectiveness of any protection mechanism that occurs in between the decoding operations.

CWE-175.Name: Improper Handling of Mixed Encoding
CWE-175.Description: The product does not properly handle when the same input uses several different (mixed) encodings.

CWE-176.Name: Improper Handling of Unicode Encoding
CWE-176.Description: The product does not properly handle when an input contains Unicode encoding.

CWE-177.Name: Improper Handling of URL Encoding (Hex Encoding)
CWE-177.Description: The product does not properly handle when all or part of an input has been URL encoded.

CWE-178.Name: Improper Handling of Case Sensitivity
CWE-178.Description: The product does not properly account for differences in case sensitivity when accessing or determining the properties of a resource, leading to inconsistent results.

CWE-179.Name: Incorrect Behavior Order: Early Validation
CWE-179.Description: The product validates input before applying protection mechanisms that modify the input, which could allow an attacker to bypass the validation via dangerous inputs that only arise after the modification.

CWE-180.Name: Incorrect Behavior Order: Validate Before Canonicalize
CWE-180.Description: The product validates input before it is canonicalized, which prevents the product from detecting data that becomes invalid after the canonicalization step.

CWE-181.Name: Incorrect Behavior Order: Validate Before Filter
CWE-181.Description: The product validates data before it has been filtered, which prevents the product from detecting data that becomes invalid after the filtering step.

CWE-182.Name: Collapse of Data into Unsafe Value
CWE-182.Description: The product filters data in a way that causes it to be reduced or "collapsed" into an unsafe value that violates an expected security property.

CWE-183.Name: Permissive List of Allowed Inputs
CWE-183.Description: The product implements a protection mechanism that relies on a list of inputs (or properties of inputs) that are explicitly allowed by policy because the inputs are assumed to be safe, but the list is too permissive - that is, it allows an input that is unsafe, leading to resultant weaknesses.

CWE-184.Name: Incomplete List of Disallowed Inputs
CWE-184.Description: The product implements a protection mechanism that relies on a list of inputs (or properties of inputs) that are not allowed by policy or otherwise require other action to neutralize before additional processing takes place, but the list is incomplete, leading to resultant weaknesses.

CWE-185.Name: Incorrect Regular Expression
CWE-185.Description: The product specifies a regular expression in a way that causes data to be improperly matched or compared.

CWE-186.Name: Overly Restrictive Regular Expression
CWE-186.Description: A regular expression is overly restrictive, which prevents dangerous values from being detected.

CWE-187.Name: Partial String Comparison
CWE-187.Description: The product performs a comparison that only examines a portion of a factor before determining whether there is a match, such as a substring, leading to resultant weaknesses.

CWE-188.Name: Reliance on Data/Memory Layout
CWE-188.Description: The product makes invalid assumptions about how protocol data or memory is organized at a lower level, resulting in unintended program behavior.

CWE-190.Name: Integer Overflow or Wraparound
CWE-190.Description:
The product performs a calculation that can
         produce an integer overflow or wraparound when the logic
         assumes that the resulting value will always be larger than
         the original value. This occurs when an integer value is
         incremented to a value that is too large to store in the
         associated representation. When this occurs, the value may
         become a very small or negative number.

CWE-191.Name: Integer Underflow (Wrap or Wraparound)
CWE-191.Description: The product subtracts one value from another, such that the result is less than the minimum allowable integer value, which produces a value that is not equal to the correct result.

CWE-192.Name: Integer Coercion Error
CWE-192.Description: Integer coercion refers to a set of flaws pertaining to the type casting, extension, or truncation of primitive data types.

CWE-193.Name: Off-by-one Error
CWE-193.Description: A product calculates or uses an incorrect maximum or minimum value that is 1 more, or 1 less, than the correct value.

CWE-194.Name: Unexpected Sign Extension
CWE-194.Description: The product performs an operation on a number that causes it to be sign extended when it is transformed into a larger data type. When the original number is negative, this can produce unexpected values that lead to resultant weaknesses.

CWE-195.Name: Signed to Unsigned Conversion Error
CWE-195.Description: The product uses a signed primitive and performs a cast to an unsigned primitive, which can produce an unexpected value if the value of the signed primitive can not be represented using an unsigned primitive.

CWE-196.Name: Unsigned to Signed Conversion Error
CWE-196.Description: The product uses an unsigned primitive and performs a cast to a signed primitive, which can produce an unexpected value if the value of the unsigned primitive can not be represented using a signed primitive.

CWE-197.Name: Numeric Truncation Error
CWE-197.Description: Truncation errors occur when a primitive is cast to a primitive of a smaller size and data is lost in the conversion.

CWE-198.Name: Use of Incorrect Byte Ordering
CWE-198.Description: The product receives input from an upstream component, but it does not account for byte ordering (e.g. big-endian and little-endian) when processing the input, causing an incorrect number or value to be used.

CWE-20.Name: Improper Input Validation
CWE-20.Description:
The product receives input or data, but it does
        not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the
        properties that are required to process the data safely and
        correctly.

CWE-200.Name: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor
CWE-200.Description: The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

CWE-201.Name: Insertion of Sensitive Information Into Sent Data
CWE-201.Description: The code transmits data to another actor, but a portion of the data includes sensitive information that should not be accessible to that actor.

CWE-202.Name: Exposure of Sensitive Information Through Data Queries
CWE-202.Description: When trying to keep information confidential, an attacker can often infer some of the information by using statistics.

CWE-203.Name: Observable Discrepancy
CWE-203.Description: The product behaves differently or sends different responses under different circumstances in a way that is observable to an unauthorized actor, which exposes security-relevant information about the state of the product, such as whether a particular operation was successful or not.

CWE-204.Name: Observable Response Discrepancy
CWE-204.Description: The product provides different responses to incoming requests in a way that reveals internal state information to an unauthorized actor outside of the intended control sphere.

CWE-205.Name: Observable Behavioral Discrepancy
CWE-205.Description: The product's behaviors indicate important differences that may be observed by unauthorized actors in a way that reveals (1) its internal state or decision process, or (2) differences from other products with equivalent functionality.

CWE-206.Name: Observable Internal Behavioral Discrepancy
CWE-206.Description: The product performs multiple behaviors that are combined to produce a single result, but the individual behaviors are observable separately in a way that allows attackers to reveal internal state or internal decision points.

CWE-207.Name: Observable Behavioral Discrepancy With Equivalent Products
CWE-207.Description: The product operates in an environment in which its existence or specific identity should not be known, but it behaves differently than other products with equivalent functionality, in a way that is observable to an attacker.

CWE-208.Name: Observable Timing Discrepancy
CWE-208.Description: Two separate operations in a product require different amounts of time to complete, in a way that is observable to an actor and reveals security-relevant information about the state of the product, such as whether a particular operation was successful or not.

CWE-209.Name: Generation of Error Message Containing Sensitive Information
CWE-209.Description: The product generates an error message that includes sensitive information about its environment, users, or associated data.

CWE-210.Name: Self-generated Error Message Containing Sensitive Information
CWE-210.Description: The product identifies an error condition and creates its own diagnostic or error messages that contain sensitive information.

CWE-211.Name: Externally-Generated Error Message Containing Sensitive Information
CWE-211.Description: The product performs an operation that triggers an external diagnostic or error message that is not directly generated or controlled by the product, such as an error generated by the programming language interpreter that a software application uses. The error can contain sensitive system information.

CWE-212.Name: Improper Removal of Sensitive Information Before Storage or Transfer
CWE-212.Description: The product stores, transfers, or shares a resource that contains sensitive information, but it does not properly remove that information before the product makes the resource available to unauthorized actors.

CWE-213.Name: Exposure of Sensitive Information Due to Incompatible Policies
CWE-213.Description: The product's intended functionality exposes information to certain actors in accordance with the developer's security policy, but this information is regarded as sensitive according to the intended security policies of other stakeholders such as the product's administrator, users, or others whose information is being processed.

CWE-214.Name: Invocation of Process Using Visible Sensitive Information
CWE-214.Description: A process is invoked with sensitive command-line arguments, environment variables, or other elements that can be seen by other processes on the operating system.

CWE-215.Name: Insertion of Sensitive Information Into Debugging Code
CWE-215.Description: The product inserts sensitive information into debugging code, which could expose this information if the debugging code is not disabled in production.

CWE-219.Name: Storage of File with Sensitive Data Under Web Root
CWE-219.Description: The product stores sensitive data under the web document root with insufficient access control, which might make it accessible to untrusted parties.

CWE-22.Name: Improper Limitation of a Pathname to a Restricted Directory ('Path Traversal')
CWE-22.Description: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that is intended to identify a file or directory that is located underneath a restricted parent directory, but the product does not properly neutralize special elements within the pathname that can cause the pathname to resolve to a location that is outside of the restricted directory.

CWE-220.Name: Storage of File With Sensitive Data Under FTP Root
CWE-220.Description: The product stores sensitive data under the FTP server root with insufficient access control, which might make it accessible to untrusted parties.

CWE-221.Name: Information Loss or Omission
CWE-221.Description: The product does not record, or improperly records, security-relevant information that leads to an incorrect decision or hampers later analysis.

CWE-222.Name: Truncation of Security-relevant Information
CWE-222.Description: The product truncates the display, recording, or processing of security-relevant information in a way that can obscure the source or nature of an attack.

CWE-223.Name: Omission of Security-relevant Information
CWE-223.Description: The product does not record or display information that would be important for identifying the source or nature of an attack, or determining if an action is safe.

CWE-224.Name: Obscured Security-relevant Information by Alternate Name
CWE-224.Description: The product records security-relevant information according to an alternate name of the affected entity, instead of the canonical name.

CWE-226.Name: Sensitive Information in Resource Not Removed Before Reuse
CWE-226.Description: The product releases a resource such as memory or a file so that it can be made available for reuse, but it does not clear or "zeroize" the information contained in the resource before the product performs a critical state transition or makes the resource available for reuse by other entities.

CWE-228.Name: Improper Handling of Syntactically Invalid Structure
CWE-228.Description: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles input that is not syntactically well-formed with respect to the associated specification.

CWE-229.Name: Improper Handling of Values
CWE-229.Description: The product does not properly handle when the expected number of values for parameters, fields, or arguments is not provided in input, or if those values are undefined.

CWE-23.Name: Relative Path Traversal
CWE-23.Description: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize sequences such as ".." that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

CWE-230.Name: Improper Handling of Missing Values
CWE-230.Description: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles when a parameter, field, or argument name is specified, but the associated value is missing, i.e. it is empty, blank, or null.

CWE-231.Name: Improper Handling of Extra Values
CWE-231.Description: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles when more values are provided than expected.

CWE-232.Name: Improper Handling of Undefined Values
CWE-232.Description: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles when a value is not defined or supported for the associated parameter, field, or argument name.

CWE-233.Name: Improper Handling of Parameters
CWE-233.Description: The product does not properly handle when the expected number of parameters, fields, or arguments is not provided in input, or if those parameters are undefined.

CWE-234.Name: Failure to Handle Missing Parameter
CWE-234.Description: If too few arguments are sent to a function, the function will still pop the expected number of arguments from the stack. Potentially, a variable number of arguments could be exhausted in a function as well.

CWE-235.Name: Improper Handling of Extra Parameters
CWE-235.Description: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles when the number of parameters, fields, or arguments with the same name exceeds the expected amount.

CWE-236.Name: Improper Handling of Undefined Parameters
CWE-236.Description: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles when a particular parameter, field, or argument name is not defined or supported by the product.

CWE-237.Name: Improper Handling of Structural Elements
CWE-237.Description: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles inputs that are related to complex structures.

CWE-238.Name: Improper Handling of Incomplete Structural Elements
CWE-238.Description: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles when a particular structural element is not completely specified.

CWE-239.Name: Failure to Handle Incomplete Element
CWE-239.Description: The product does not properly handle when a particular element is not completely specified.

CWE-24.Name: Path Traversal: '../filedir'
CWE-24.Description: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize "../" sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

CWE-240.Name: Improper Handling of Inconsistent Structural Elements
CWE-240.Description: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles when two or more structural elements should be consistent, but are not.

CWE-241.Name: Improper Handling of Unexpected Data Type
CWE-241.Description: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles when a particular element is not the expected type, e.g. it expects a digit (0-9) but is provided with a letter (A-Z).

CWE-242.Name: Use of Inherently Dangerous Function
CWE-242.Description: The product calls a function that can never be guaranteed to work safely.

CWE-244.Name: Improper Clearing of Heap Memory Before Release ('Heap Inspection')
CWE-244.Description: Using realloc() to resize buffers that store sensitive information can leave the sensitive information exposed to attack, because it is not removed from memory.

CWE-248.Name: Uncaught Exception
CWE-248.Description: An exception is thrown from a function, but it is not caught.

CWE-25.Name: Path Traversal: '/../filedir'
CWE-25.Description: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize "/../" sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

CWE-250.Name: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges
CWE-250.Description: The product performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.

CWE-252.Name: Unchecked Return Value
CWE-252.Description: The product does not check the return value from a method or function, which can prevent it from detecting unexpected states and conditions.

CWE-253.Name: Incorrect Check of Function Return Value
CWE-253.Description: The product incorrectly checks a return value from a function, which prevents it from detecting errors or exceptional conditions.

CWE-256.Name: Plaintext Storage of a Password
CWE-256.Description: Storing a password in plaintext may result in a system compromise.

CWE-257.Name: Storing Passwords in a Recoverable Format
CWE-257.Description: The storage of passwords in a recoverable format makes them subject to password reuse attacks by malicious users. In fact, it should be noted that recoverable encrypted passwords provide no significant benefit over plaintext passwords since they are subject not only to reuse by malicious attackers but also by malicious insiders. If a system administrator can recover a password directly, or use a brute force search on the available information, the administrator can use the password on other accounts.

CWE-258.Name: Empty Password in Configuration File
CWE-258.Description: Using an empty string as a password is insecure.

CWE-259.Name: Use of Hard-coded Password
CWE-259.Description: The product contains a hard-coded password, which it uses for its own inbound authentication or for outbound communication to external components.

CWE-26.Name: Path Traversal: '/dir/../filename'
CWE-26.Description: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize "/dir/../filename" sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

CWE-260.Name: Password in Configuration File
CWE-260.Description: The product stores a password in a configuration file that might be accessible to actors who do not know the password.

CWE-261.Name: Weak Encoding for Password
CWE-261.Description: Obscuring a password with a trivial encoding does not protect the password.

CWE-262.Name: Not Using Password Aging
CWE-262.Description: The product does not have a mechanism in place for managing password aging.

CWE-263.Name: Password Aging with Long Expiration
CWE-263.Description: The product supports password aging, but the expiration period is too long.

CWE-266.Name: Incorrect Privilege Assignment
CWE-266.Description: A product incorrectly assigns a privilege to a particular actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

CWE-267.Name: Privilege Defined With Unsafe Actions
CWE-267.Description: A particular privilege, role, capability, or right can be used to perform unsafe actions that were not intended, even when it is assigned to the correct entity.

CWE-268.Name: Privilege Chaining
CWE-268.Description: Two distinct privileges, roles, capabilities, or rights can be combined in a way that allows an entity to perform unsafe actions that would not be allowed without that combination.

CWE-269.Name: Improper Privilege Management
CWE-269.Description: The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

CWE-27.Name: Path Traversal: 'dir/../../filename'
CWE-27.Description: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize multiple internal "../" sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

CWE-270.Name: Privilege Context Switching Error
CWE-270.Description: The product does not properly manage privileges while it is switching between different contexts that have different privileges or spheres of control.

CWE-271.Name: Privilege Dropping / Lowering Errors
CWE-271.Description: The product does not drop privileges before passing control of a resource to an actor that does not have those privileges.

CWE-272.Name: Least Privilege Violation
CWE-272.Description: The elevated privilege level required to perform operations such as chroot() should be dropped immediately after the operation is performed.

CWE-273.Name: Improper Check for Dropped Privileges
CWE-273.Description: The product attempts to drop privileges but does not check or incorrectly checks to see if the drop succeeded.

CWE-274.Name: Improper Handling of Insufficient Privileges
CWE-274.Description: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles when it has insufficient privileges to perform an operation, leading to resultant weaknesses.

CWE-276.Name: Incorrect Default Permissions
CWE-276.Description: During installation, installed file permissions are set to allow anyone to modify those files.

CWE-277.Name: Insecure Inherited Permissions
CWE-277.Description: A product defines a set of insecure permissions that are inherited by objects that are created by the program.

CWE-278.Name: Insecure Preserved Inherited Permissions
CWE-278.Description: A product inherits a set of insecure permissions for an object, e.g. when copying from an archive file, without user awareness or involvement.

CWE-279.Name: Incorrect Execution-Assigned Permissions
CWE-279.Description: While it is executing, the product sets the permissions of an object in a way that violates the intended permissions that have been specified by the user.

CWE-28.Name: Path Traversal: '..\filedir'
CWE-28.Description: The product uses external input to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize "..\" sequences that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory.

CWE-280.Name: Improper Handling of Insufficient Permissions or Privileges
CWE-280.Description: The product does not handle or incorrectly handles when it has insufficient privileges to access resources or functionality as specified by their permissions. This may cause it to follow unexpected code paths that may leave the product in an invalid state.

CWE-281.Name: Improper Preservation of Permissions
CWE-281.Description: The product does not preserve permissions or incorrectly preserves permissions when copying, restoring, or sharing objects, which can cause them to have less restrictive permissions than intended.

CWE-282.Name: Improper Ownership Management
CWE-282.Description: The product assigns the wrong ownership, or does not properly verify the ownership, of an object or resource.

CWE-283.Name: Unverified Ownership
CWE-283.Description: The product does not properly verify that a critical resource is owned by the proper entity.

CWE-284.Name: Improper Access Control
CWE-284.Description: The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

CWE-285.Name: Improper Authorization
CWE-285.Description: The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

CWE-286.Name: Incorrect User Management
CWE-286.Description: The product does not properly manage a user within its environment.

CWE-287.Name: Improper Authentication
